name: Skálholt Cathedral - Southern Iceland's Ancient Episcopal Seat
description: Skálholt represents Iceland's religious, cultural, and educational heart for over 700 years, established as bishopric in 1056 and serving alongside Hólar as one of Iceland's two episcopal sees until 1785, positioning it as political and spiritual power center that shaped Icelandic society through medieval Catholic period, Protestant Reformation, and early modern Lutheran era until authority transferred to Reykjavík in 1801. The establishment of Episcopal see in 1056 predated Hólar's northern diocese by 50 years, making Skálholt Iceland's first bishopric and demonstrating southern Iceland's earlier adoption of organized ecclesiastical hierarchy during period when Christianity remained relatively new (Iceland converted circa 1000 AD) and church infrastructure remained underdeveloped compared to continental Europe. Skálholt hosted 32 Catholic bishops from 1056 until Reformation in 1550, followed by 13 Lutheran bishops from 1550 to 1801, with these 45 bishops wielding enormous secular power beyond spiritual authority: they controlled vast land holdings, collected tithes, influenced legal proceedings, and participated in Iceland's limited self-governance under Norwegian and later Danish rule.
address: Skálholt, 801 Selfoss, South Iceland (along Hvítá river)
